news_summary: Today's positive news highlights breakthroughs in understanding vibrant bird colors and ancient feathered reptiles, alongside a successful US-Japan trade deal that averts hefty tariffs.
news_summary_fr: Les nouvelles positives d'aujourd'hui mettent en lumière les avancées dans la compréhension des couleurs vives des oiseaux et des anciens reptiles à plumes, ainsi que l'accord commercial conclu entre les États-Unis et le Japon, qui permet d'éviter des droits de douane élevés.
news_summary_es: Las noticias positivas de hoy destacan los avances en la comprensión de los vibrantes colores de las aves y los antiguos reptiles emplumados, junto con el éxito de un acuerdo comercial entre EE.UU. y Japón que evita la imposición de fuertes aranceles.

articles.title: The secret to what makes colours pop on dazzling songbirds
articles.summary: Hidden layers of colour in the plumage of tanagers and some other songbirds explain what makes them so eye-catching
articles.content:
Hidden layers of colour in the plumage of tanagers and some other songbirds explain what makes them so eye-catching

Green-headed tanagers (Tangara seledon) are strikingly colourful Daniel Field

Brightly coloured songbirds called tanagers are so eye-catching because they have a hidden layer of black or white beneath their dazzling plumage.

Painters often prime a canvas with a layer of white to enhance the colours they will eventually layer on, as well as to make it smoother and stronger. But it seems this is a mechanism that birds were using long before humans picked up paintbrushes.

Advertisement

Rosalyn Price-Waldman at Princeton University and her colleagues have found that when songbirds in the tanager genus Tangara have bright red or yellow plumage, they usually have white layers hidden underneath. When they have blue plumage, they have black layers beneath.

To investigate why, they removed 72 feathers from taxidermied tanager specimens in the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County’s collection.

By taking pictures of the feathers on different backgrounds, the team measured how their reflectance or absorption of light changed, finding that the underlayers make the top layers look more colourful.

Free newsletter Sign up to The Earth Edition Unmissable news about our planet, delivered straight to your inbox each month. Sign up to newsletter

The red and yellow colouration is created by pigments, which are molecules that selectively absorb light to make colour. This means backscattering light from the white below makes them brighter, says Price-Waldman.

But blue colouration is created by nanostructures within the feathers that selectively scatter light, rather than absorbing light to create the colour we see. Because of this, the light-absorbing black below makes the blue look brighter. “If you have white underneath them, they look a white-grey colour,” says Price-Waldman.

The overall effect of the plumage is created because feathers are layered like tiles on a roof, she says. When you take a single feather, it may have a colourful tip, an intermediate region of either black or white and then the fluffy, downy base. When these feathers are layered on the body, the tips create a contiguous layer of colour, above a contiguous layer of white or black.

Blue feathers on the crown of a red-necked tanager (Tangara cyanocephala) are intensified by a layer of black plumage underneath Rosalyn Price-Waldman, Allison Shultz

Price-Waldman and her colleagues also found that, in some cases, these layers of feathers generate the differences in colour between the sexes.

“We found a few cases where the females had black underneath yellow and the males had white underneath yellow,” she says. “When you put their feathers on the same background, the feathers actually look really similar. It’s not until you take the male feathers and put them on white and the female feathers on a black background that you really get the large differences in colouration that you see.”

The researchers found that this colour-boosting strategy is seen in many other songbirds, including manakins and cotingas.

“While a lot of research has already been done to understand how birds produce such striking colours, there is clearly a lot left to discover,” says Chris Cooney at the University of Sheffield, UK. “It appears that this ‘hidden’ mechanism for enhancing the brightness of plumage colours may actually be rather widespread across bird species.”
articles.reasoning: The article reveals a scientific discovery explaining the vibrant colors of songbirds, which is a positive scientific breakthrough that can inspire curiosity and appreciation for nature.
articles.personality_title: The secret behind the bright colors of dazzling songbirds
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Brightly colored songbirds called tanagers have long fascinated people with their stunning plumage. Scientists have wondered what makes their feathers look so vibrant and eye-catching.

**What happened**
Researchers discovered that tanagers have a hidden layer of black or white beneath their colorful feathers. This layer acts like a primer, similar to how painters use a white base to make paint colors stand out better. This secret layer enhances the brightness and sharpness of the bird's colors.

**Impact**
This discovery helps us understand how nature creates such beautiful and vivid colors. It also shows how animals use clever tricks to stand out, which can inspire both science and art. Knowing this can deepen our appreciation for these amazing birds and the natural world.

**What's next step**
Scientists plan to study other birds to see if they use similar hidden layers of color. This could reveal more about how animals develop their unique appearances and how those traits evolved over time.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Hidden layers beneath feathers make tanagers’ colors shine brighter, unlocking nature’s secret to dazzling bird beauty.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le secret des couleurs éclatantes des oiseaux chanteurs éblouissants
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les oiseaux chanteurs brillamment colorés appelés tangaras fascinent depuis longtemps par leur plumage éclatant. Les scientifiques se demandaient ce qui rend leurs plumes si vibrantes et attrayantes.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Les chercheurs ont découvert que les tangaras ont une couche cachée de noir ou de blanc sous leurs plumes colorées. Cette couche agit comme une sous-couche, un peu comme les peintres qui utilisent un fond blanc pour faire ressortir les couleurs. Cette couche secrète améliore la luminosité et la netteté des couleurs des oiseaux.

**Impact**
Cette découverte nous aide à comprendre comment la nature crée des couleurs aussi belles et vives. Elle montre aussi comment les animaux utilisent des astuces ingénieuses pour se démarquer, ce qui peut inspirer la science et l’art. Cela enrichit notre admiration pour ces oiseaux étonnants et le monde naturel.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les scientifiques prévoient d’étudier d’autres oiseaux pour voir s’ils utilisent des couches cachées similaires. Cela pourrait révéler comment les animaux développent leurs apparences uniques et comment ces traits ont évolué.

**Une phrase à retenir**
Les couches cachées sous les plumes rendent les couleurs des tangaras plus éclatantes, révélant le secret de la beauté éblouissante des oiseaux dans la nature.
articles.personality_title_es: El secreto detrás de los colores brillantes de los pájaros cantores deslumbrantes
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los pájaros cantores brillantemente coloridos llamados tangaras han fascinado durante mucho tiempo con su plumaje impresionante. Los científicos se preguntaban qué hace que sus plumas sean tan vibrantes y llamativas.

**Qué pasó**
Los investigadores descubrieron que las tangaras tienen una capa oculta de negro o blanco debajo de sus plumas coloridas. Esta capa actúa como una base, similar a cómo los pintores usan una base blanca para hacer que los colores resalten mejor. Esta capa secreta mejora el brillo y la nitidez de los colores del ave.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento nos ayuda a entender cómo la naturaleza crea colores tan hermosos y vivos. También muestra cómo los animales usan trucos inteligentes para destacar, lo que puede inspirar tanto a la ciencia como al arte. Conocer esto puede profundizar nuestra admiración por estas aves asombrosas y el mundo natural.

**Próximo paso**
Los científicos planean estudiar otras aves para ver si usan capas ocultas similares. Esto podría revelar más sobre cómo los animales desarrollan sus apariencias únicas y cómo evolucionaron esos rasgos con el tiempo.

**Una frase para recordar**
Las capas ocultas debajo de las plumas hacen que los colores de las tangaras brillen más, revelando el secreto de la belleza deslumbrante de las aves en la naturaleza.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of vibrant tanager songbirds perched with their layered feathers partially translucent to reveal hidden black and white underlayers beneath dazzling red, yellow, and blue plumage, set against a soft natural background with gentle light emphasizing the brightness and depth of their colors.

articles.title: Spectacular Triassic reptile had an early kind of feathers
articles.summary: A 247-million-year-old fossil reptile boasted an enormous crest on its back made from feather-like appendages, long before the appearance of feathered dinosaurs
articles.content:
A 247-million-year-old fossil reptile boasted an enormous crest on its back made from feather-like appendages, long before the appearance of feathered dinosaurs

Illustration of the Triassic reptile Mirasaura grauvogeli Rick Stikkelorum

A reptile from the Middle Triassic had a spectacular crest made from feather-like structures, around 100 million years before the first feathered dinosaurs.

Its remains comprise two fossils with the skeleton and crest and 80 fossils of just the crest, all found by a private collector called Louis Grauvogel between the 1930s and 1970s in the Vosges mountains of northeastern France.

Advertisement

It wasn’t until 2018, when Stephan Spiekman at the State Museum of Natural History Stuttgart, Germany, and his colleagues were able to study the fossils, that they realised the skeletal and crest remains were from the same species, one new to science.

They have now formally described it, naming it Mirasaura grauvogeli – partly derived from the Latin for marvellous lizard on account of its extravagant crest.

It was very surprising to find such a complex skin outgrowth in an animal dating back 247 million years, early in the evolution of reptiles, says Spiekman.

Free newsletter Sign up to The Earth Edition Unmissable news about our planet, delivered straight to your inbox each month. Sign up to newsletter

“It is definitely a very extravagant structure that was larger than the entire torso of the animal. The crest was composed of individual appendages that would have tightly overlapped each other, similar to feathers in a bird wing,” he says.

While M. grauvogeli‘s appendages had a differentiated structure similar to feathers, there were also key differences. “In feathers, this differentiation is formed through a complex branching process, which forms the barbs, barbules and rachis of a feather, [but] no such branching is present in the Mirasaura appendages,” says Spiekman.

The most complete specimen of M. grauvogeli is less than 15 centimetres long, but is clearly a juvenile due to several features of its skeleton, he says.

A fossil preserving the skeleton of Mirasaura grauvogeli Stephan Spiekman

One of the fossilised crests is three times the length of the best-preserved small individual, suggesting that M. grauvogeli could get much bigger than this. Spiekman says the maximum size of an adult was probably between 50 and 100 centimetres.

“The overall build of Mirasaura would have been that of an agile climber, something similar to a chameleon or a tree-living mammal,” he says.

John Long at Flinders University in Adelaide, Australia, who wasn’t involved in the study, says it is a “truly incredible” prehistoric critter.

“It shows evolution was experimenting with how to make a feather from reptilian skin, but it didn’t quite work,” says Long. “It’s likely these huge crests on the back were for signalling and visual communication rather than having a flight function.”
articles.reasoning: The discovery of a 247-million-year-old reptile with feather-like appendages represents a significant scientific breakthrough that enhances our understanding of evolutionary history. This kind of paleontological finding is inspiring and educational, sparking curiosity and hope about uncovering more about life on Earth.
articles.personality_title: Ancient reptile sported feather-like crest long before dinosaurs
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists recently discovered fossils of a reptile from the Middle Triassic period, about 247 million years ago. This was long before dinosaurs with feathers appeared.

**What happened**
The reptile, named Mirasaura grauvogeli, had a large, impressive crest on its back made from feather-like structures. Researchers found two fossils showing the skeleton and crest, plus 80 fossils of just the crest.

**Impact**
This finding changes what we thought about when feather-like features first evolved. It shows these features appeared much earlier than the first feathered dinosaurs, giving us new insight into the evolution of ancient reptiles.

**What's next step**
Scientists will study these fossils more closely to understand how and why these feather-like structures developed. This could reveal more about the diversity and survival strategies of early reptiles.

**One-sentence takeaway**
This 247-million-year-old reptile reminds us that nature’s creativity with feathers started far earlier than we imagined.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un reptile ancien arborait une crête plumeuse bien avant les dinosaures
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les scientifiques ont récemment découvert des fossiles d’un reptile du Trias moyen, il y a environ 247 millions d’années. C’était bien avant l’apparition des dinosaures à plumes.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Le reptile, appelé Mirasaura grauvogeli, possédait une grande crête impressionnante sur le dos, faite de structures semblables à des plumes. Les chercheurs ont trouvé deux fossiles avec le squelette et la crête, ainsi que 80 fossiles de la seule crête.

**Impact**
Cette découverte change notre vision de l’apparition des traits plumeux. Elle montre que ces caractéristiques sont apparues bien avant les premiers dinosaures à plumes, offrant un nouveau regard sur l’évolution des reptiles anciens.

**Prochaine étape**
Les scientifiques vont étudier ces fossiles en détail pour comprendre comment et pourquoi ces structures plumeuses se sont formées. Cela pourrait révéler davantage sur la diversité et les stratégies de survie des premiers reptiles.

**Une phrase à retenir**
Ce reptile vieux de 247 millions d’années nous rappelle que la créativité de la nature avec les plumes a commencé bien plus tôt qu’on ne le pensait.
articles.personality_title_es: Un antiguo reptil tenía una cresta con aspecto de plumas mucho antes de los dinosaurios
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Científicos descubrieron recientemente fósiles de un reptil del período Triásico Medio, hace unos 247 millones de años. Esto fue mucho antes de que aparecieran los dinosaurios con plumas.

**Qué pasó**
El reptil, llamado Mirasaura grauvogeli, tenía una gran y llamativa cresta en la espalda formada por estructuras similares a plumas. Los investigadores encontraron dos fósiles con el esqueleto y la cresta, además de 80 fósiles solo de la cresta.

**Impacto**
Este hallazgo cambia nuestra idea sobre cuándo aparecieron las características parecidas a plumas. Muestra que estas aparecieron mucho antes que los primeros dinosaurios con plumas, dándonos una nueva perspectiva sobre la evolución de los reptiles antiguos.

**Próximo paso**
Los científicos estudiarán estos fósiles más a fondo para entender cómo y por qué se desarrollaron estas estructuras similares a plumas. Esto podría revelar más sobre la diversidad y las estrategias de supervivencia de los primeros reptiles.

**Una frase para recordar**
Este reptil de 247 millones de años nos recuerda que la creatividad de la naturaleza con las plumas comenzó mucho antes de lo que imaginábamos.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a small, agile Triassic reptile with a magnificent, overlapping feather-like crest along its back, perched gracefully on a rocky outcrop in the ancient Vosges mountains, rendered in soft natural earth tones and gentle greens to evoke prehistoric life and early evolutionary wonder.

articles.title: US and Japan strike trade deal, avoiding Trump's threat of 25% tariffs
articles.summary: After months of negotiations, the US has reached a trade deal with Japan. US President Donald Trump celebrated the agreement on tariffs in a social media post, while Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba hailed the deal, which sets duties on Japanese exports to the US at a rate of 15 percent. In this edition, we look at what exactly has been announced by both sides and what it means for Japan's auto sector, which is responsible for a quarter of all exports to the US.
articles.content:
US and Japan strike trade deal, avoiding Trump's threat of 25% tariffs

Business

To display this content from YouTube, you must enable advertisement tracking and audience measurement. Accept Manage my choices One of your browser extensions seems to be blocking the video player from loading. To watch this content, you may need to disable it on this site. Try again BUSINESS © FRANCE 24 05:52

05:52 min

Play (05:52 min)

From the show

Reading time 1 min

After months of negotiations, the US has reached a trade deal with Japan. US President Donald Trump celebrated the agreement on tariffs in a social media post, while Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba hailed the deal, which sets duties on Japanese exports to the US at a rate of 15 percent. In this edition, we look at what exactly has been announced by both sides and what it means for Japan's auto sector, which is responsible for a quarter of all exports to the US.
articles.source: Business news, technology, media and finance reports - France 24
articles.reasoning: The trade deal between the US and Japan avoids the imposition of higher tariffs, which is positive for economic relations and stability. It benefits the auto sector and likely supports jobs and economic growth, which can be hopeful for many people. While it is a political and economic story, it reflects cooperation and a positive resolution.
articles.personality_title: US and Japan reach trade deal, avoiding steep tariffs on cars
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
The US had threatened to impose a 25% tax on Japanese goods, especially cars, to protect American businesses. This alarmed many because such high taxes could make Japanese products more expensive, affecting trade between the two countries.

**What happened**
After months of talks, the US and Japan agreed on a deal where Japan’s exports to the US will face a 15% tariff instead of 25%. This compromise came after negotiations aimed at keeping trade smooth and fair for both sides.

**Impact**
This deal is great news for Japan’s car industry, which makes up a big part of exports to the US. Lower tariffs mean cars and parts stay more affordable, helping companies keep jobs and encouraging economic growth in both countries.

**What's next step**
Both countries will now work on implementing the agreement details and look for ways to strengthen their trade relationship further, ensuring benefits continue and disagreements are managed peacefully.

**One-sentence takeaway**
The US and Japan’s new trade deal lowers tariffs, protecting jobs and boosting economic ties between the two nations.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les États-Unis et le Japon concluent un accord commercial évitant des tarifs élevés sur les voitures
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les États-Unis menaçaient d’imposer une taxe de 25 % sur les produits japonais, surtout les voitures, pour protéger leurs entreprises. Cela inquiétait car ces taxes élevées auraient rendu les produits japonais plus chers, perturbant le commerce entre les deux pays.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Après des mois de négociations, les États-Unis et le Japon ont trouvé un accord : les exportations japonaises vers les États-Unis auront une taxe de 15 % au lieu de 25 %. Ce compromis vise à maintenir un commerce juste et fluide.

**Impact**
Cette bonne nouvelle concerne surtout l’industrie automobile japonaise, qui représente une grande partie des exportations vers les États-Unis. Des tarifs plus bas permettent de garder les voitures abordables, de préserver les emplois et de favoriser la croissance économique des deux pays.

**Prochaine étape**
Les deux pays vont maintenant mettre en place les détails de l’accord et chercher à renforcer leur relation commerciale pour garantir des bénéfices durables et gérer les désaccords calmement.

**Résumé en une phrase**
Le nouvel accord commercial entre les États-Unis et le Japon réduit les tarifs, protégeant les emplois et renforçant les liens économiques entre les deux pays.
articles.personality_title_es: Estados Unidos y Japón logran acuerdo comercial que evita altos aranceles a autos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Estados Unidos había amenazado con imponer un impuesto del 25 % a los productos japoneses, especialmente autos, para proteger a sus empresas. Esto preocupaba porque esos impuestos altos podrían encarecer los productos japoneses y afectar el comercio entre ambos países.

**Qué pasó**
Tras meses de negociaciones, Estados Unidos y Japón acordaron que las exportaciones japonesas a Estados Unidos tendrán un arancel del 15 % en lugar del 25 %. Este compromiso busca mantener un comercio justo y fluido.

**Impacto**
Esta noticia es especialmente buena para la industria automotriz japonesa, que representa gran parte de las exportaciones a Estados Unidos. Los aranceles más bajos mantienen los autos asequibles, protegen empleos y fomentan el crecimiento económico en ambos países.

**Próximo paso**
Ahora, ambos países trabajarán en implementar los detalles del acuerdo y buscarán fortalecer su relación comercial para asegurar beneficios continuos y manejar desacuerdos de forma pacífica.

**Resumen en una frase**
El nuevo acuerdo comercial entre Estados Unidos y Japón reduce aranceles, protegiendo empleos y reforzando los lazos económicos entre las dos naciones.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of two stylized, interlocking gears—one decorated with the American flag colors and the other with the Japanese flag colors—set against a softly glowing background, symbolizing cooperation and smooth trade relations, with subtle imagery of cars and shipping containers woven into the gear patterns to represent the auto export sector.

articles.title: Teeth marks suggest 'terror bird' was killed by reptile 13 million years ago
articles.summary: Terror birds could be taller than a human and had powerful legs and hooked, flesh-ripping beaks.
articles.content:
Teeth marks suggest 'terror bird' was killed by reptile 13 million years ago

1 day ago Share Save Victoria Gill Science correspondent, BBC News Share Save

Link et al/Biology Letters The researchers say the terror bird did not survive the encounter

Teeth marks made on the leg bone of a large avian reptile known as a terror bird 13 million years ago suggest an even bigger predator may have killed it, scientists say. Terror birds were top predators - they could be taller than a human and had powerful legs and hooked, flesh-ripping beaks. Palaeontologists in Colombia matched teeth marks on the fossilised leg bone of one of these fearsome birds to a caiman, or a crocodile-like reptile. 3D digital scans of the bites allowed the scientists to reconstruct what they believe was a "battle to the death" that the terror bird did not survive.

Link et al/Biology Letters The researchers scanned the teeth marks in the leg bone and compared it with skulls and teeth of crocodile-like predators

The new study, published in the journal Biology Letters, compared the size and shape of the teeth marks to the skulls and teeth of crocodile-like predators in museum collections. It provides rare evidence, the researchers say, of an interaction between two extinct top predators at the time. The leg bone the scientists studied was first unearthed more than 15 years ago in Colombia's Tatacoa Desert. When the bird lived in the swamps of that area 13 million years ago, it would have been about 2.5m tall and would have used its legs and beak to hold down and rip at its prey. What the scientists are not able to prove conclusively is whether this particular, unfortunate terror bird was killed in the attack, or if the caiman scavenged its remains. "There is no sign of healing in the bite marks on the bone," explained lead researcher Andres Link from the Universidad de Los Andes in Bogotá, Colombia. "So if it wasn't already dead, it died in the attack. That was the last day that bird was on this planet - then a piece of its leg bone was found 13 million years later." 200 million year-old flying reptile is new species

Terror birds had deep voices, fossils suggest

Andres Link The teeth marks are clearly visible on the piece of leg bone

The Tatacoa Desert is home to rich deposits of fossils from an epoch known as the Middle Miocene. At that time, it was a humid swamp, where river sediments trapped and fossilised the bones of dead animals, resulting in the preserved remains found there today. This particular bone was first discovered about 15 years ago by local fossil collector César Augusto Perdomo. The Colombian scientists worked closely with Mr Perdomo, studying and cataloging fossils that he has gathered in his museum. It was when scientists were working in the museum that they realised that this fist-sized piece of leg bone came from a terror bird. That was an exciting discovery - terror bird fossils are rare. But Dr Link and his colleagues were also fascinated by the puncture marks in the bone, which had clearly been made by the teeth of another powerful predator.

Andres Link César Augusto Perdomo has been collecting fossils since he was a child
articles.reasoning: The discovery provides interesting scientific insights into prehistoric life, contributing to our understanding of natural history and evolution, which can be inspiring and educational for many people.
articles.personality_title: Ancient teeth marks reveal how a terror bird met its match 13 million years ago
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Terror birds were giant, flightless predators that lived millions of years ago. They stood taller than a person and had strong legs and hooked beaks designed for tearing flesh, making them fearsome hunters of their time.

**What happened**
Scientists discovered teeth marks on the leg bone of a terror bird fossil, showing it was attacked and likely killed by a much larger reptile. This finding comes from a bone dated to 13 million years ago, revealing a rare glimpse into how these ancient creatures interacted.

**Impact**
This discovery helps us better understand the food chain and survival struggles in prehistoric times. It shows that even top predators like terror birds faced deadly threats, giving us a clearer picture of the natural history and evolution of life on Earth.

**What's next step**
Researchers plan to study more fossils with similar bite marks to learn about the predators that lived alongside terror birds. This could uncover new details about the ancient ecosystems and the animals that shared the land.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Ancient teeth marks on a terror bird bone reveal it was killed by a bigger predator, offering valuable insights into prehistoric life and survival.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des marques de dents anciennes révèlent comment un oiseau-terreur a rencontré son rival il y a 13 millions d'années
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les oiseaux-terreur étaient de grands prédateurs incapables de voler, vivant il y a des millions d'années. Ils étaient plus grands qu'un humain et avaient des pattes solides ainsi que des becs crochus pour déchirer la chair, ce qui en faisait des chasseurs redoutables.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Des scientifiques ont découvert des marques de dents sur l'os d'une patte d'oiseau-terreur fossile, montrant qu'il a été attaqué et probablement tué par un reptile beaucoup plus grand. Cet os date d'il y a 13 millions d'années, offrant un aperçu rare des interactions de ces créatures anciennes.

**Impact**
Cette découverte nous aide à mieux comprendre la chaîne alimentaire et les luttes pour la survie à l'époque préhistorique. Elle montre que même les prédateurs au sommet comme les oiseaux-terreur faisaient face à de graves menaces, ce qui éclaire notre vision de l'histoire naturelle et de l'évolution.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs vont étudier d'autres fossiles avec des marques de morsure similaires pour en apprendre plus sur les prédateurs qui vivaient aux côtés des oiseaux-terreur. Cela pourrait révéler de nouveaux détails sur les écosystèmes anciens et les animaux qui partageaient ces terres.

**En résumé**
Des marques de dents anciennes sur un os d'oiseau-terreur révèlent qu'il a été tué par un plus grand prédateur, offrant des informations précieuses sur la vie et la survie préhistoriques.
articles.personality_title_es: Marcas de dientes antiguas revelan cómo un ave del terror encontró a su rival hace 13 millones de años
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Las aves del terror eran grandes depredadores que no podían volar y vivieron hace millones de años. Eran más altas que una persona y tenían patas fuertes y picos ganchudos para desgarrar carne, lo que las hacía cazadores temibles.

**Qué pasó**
Científicos encontraron marcas de dientes en el hueso de una pata de un ave del terror fosilizado, mostrando que fue atacado y probablemente muerto por un reptil mucho más grande. Este hueso tiene 13 millones de años, ofreciendo una rara mirada a cómo estas criaturas antiguas interactuaban.

**Impacto**
Este hallazgo nos ayuda a entender mejor la cadena alimenticia y las luchas de supervivencia en tiempos prehistóricos. Muestra que incluso depredadores principales como las aves del terror enfrentaban amenazas letales, dándonos una imagen más clara de la historia natural y la evolución.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores planean estudiar más fósiles con marcas de mordida similares para aprender sobre los depredadores que vivían junto a las aves del terror. Esto podría revelar nuevos detalles sobre los ecosistemas antiguos y los animales que compartían la tierra.

**Resumen en una frase**
Marcas de dientes antiguas en un hueso de ave del terror revelan que fue matado por un depredador más grande, ofreciendo valiosas ideas sobre la vida y supervivencia prehistóricas.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a towering, powerful terror bird with strong legs and hooked beak standing amidst a lush, prehistoric swamp, its leg bone marked with distinct crocodile-like teeth impressions, while a large, watchful caiman with textured scales lurks nearby in gentle earth tones, symbolizing their ancient confrontation.
